pages.text:
Title: Torsion in the bordism of oriented involutions

Abstract: In the bordism theory <inline-formula content-type="math/mathml"> <mml:math xmlns:mml="1998/Math/MathML" alttext="normal upper Omega Subscript asterisk Baseline left-parenthesis upper Z 2 Superscript k Baseline right-parenthesis"> <mml:semantics> <mml:mrow> <mml:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Ω<!-- Ω --></mml:mi> <mml:mo>∗<!-- ∗ --></mml:mo> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\Omega _ \ast }(Z_2^k)</mml:annotation> </mml:semantics> </mml:math> </inline-formula> of smooth, orientation-preserving <inline-formula content-type="math/mathml"> <mml:math xmlns:mml="1998/Math/MathML" alttext="upper Z 2 Superscript k"> <mml:semantics> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z_2^k</mml:annotation> </mml:semantics> </mml:math> </inline-formula>-actions all torsion has order two. Furthermore, the torsion classes inject in the unoriented theory <inline-formula content-type="math/mathml"> <mml:math xmlns:mml="1998/Math/MathML" alttext="upper N Subscript asterisk Baseline left-parenthesis upper Z 2 Superscript k Baseline right-parenthesis"> <mml:semantics> <mml:mrow> <mml:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∗<!-- ∗ --></mml:mo> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{N_ \ast }(Z_2^k)</mml:annotation> </mml:semantics> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, and any class represented by a stationary-point free action has infinite order. In addition, a procedure is given for producing Smith constructions in some generality.
